option.title: Restaurant Server
option.copy:
Position available at casual restaurant with a fast-paced and fun atmosphere. Must have flexible schedule and some experience.
Pay: $2.13/hr. + tips Hours: Variable

option.title: Warehouse Worker
option.copy:
Now hiring a warehouse associate in packing and shipping. Must be able to lift 20 pounds and have reliable transportation.
Pay: $9/hr. Hours: 12p-7p

option.title: Temp
option.copy:
Administrative skills needed. If you know your way around an office, we’ve got positions for you. Temporary workers needed for positions in offices around the area.
Hours: Variable Pay: $9/hr.

option.title: Opt in
option.copy:
Well, now you’ve got health insurance, but you’ve also reduced your weekly paycheck by almost $70.
Even when health insurance is offered, many low-income workers often opt out because they can’t afford the high premiums.

option.title: Opt out
option.copy: Even when health insurance is offered, the premiums are often so high that many low-income workers opt out – just like you did. Let’s hope you don’t get sick!

option.title: 0 – 5 miles away
option.copy: Fortunately, you can bike or walk to work. Unfortunately, you won’t be able to ditch your car altogether. Like more than 50 percent of American households, your access to public transit is too limited to go completely carless.

option.title: < 15 miles away
option.copy: A lack of affordable housing is the number one cause of homelessness.The definition of “affordable” housing is 30 percent of income, but you and over 12 million other American households spend way more on housing.

option.title: > 15 miles away
option.copy: A lack of affordable housing is the number one cause of homelessness.You chose to live farther away from your job, so your rent is lower. But your gas costs are higher. In fact, for every dollar a working family saves on housing, they spend an additional 77 cents on transportation.

option.title: Ask a friend to store it
option.facebookCopy: I can’t afford my house, so I’m downsizing to a smaller place. Can I store some stuff at your house?

option.title: Have a yard sale
option.copy: You sold a bunch of stuff, but only made $150.

option.title: Continue
option.copy:
Bank fees and overdraft charges overwhelmingly impact low-income groups, which is why many skip the bank altogether in favor of
check-cashing services.

option.title: Confront them
option.copy: You talk with them and everything seems OK. Two hours later, the temp agency calls to say that you need to pack up your stuff and leave. Apparently, you’re not a “good fit” for this company — or any other.

option.title: Confess that it was you
option.copy: The manager at the temp agency is infuriated that you lied and fires you on the spot. You don’t have to pay for the vase, but now you don’t have an income.

option.title: Keep quiet
option.copy: The temp agency fires your co-worker. As she collects her things, she confides to you that she has no idea how she’ll take care of her two children.

option.title: Pay cell phone bill ($75)
option.copy: Your phone will stay on, but you’d better drive carefully! In tough economic times, the rates of uninsured drivers rise. Not because people don’t care about insurance – but because, like you, they can’t afford it.

option.title: Pay car insurance ($100)
option.copy:
Your cell phone has been disconnected
for non-payment.

When payday comes, you can reconnect, but in addition to your bill, you’ll have to pay a $25 fee.

option.title: Borrow money from a friend
option.facebookCopy: I can’t pay all my bills this month, and I need to borrow $175. Can you help me out?

option.title: Pay gas bill ($100)
option.copy: Your electricity has been cut off. But you’re not alone – it happened to 4.3 million Americans last year. Be prepared to pay your bill plus a $250 deposit to get your electricity turned back on.

option.title: Pay electric bill ($125)
option.copy: Your gas has been cut off, which means no heat, no hot water, no way to cook. You can get it turned back on, but it’ll cost you a $200 deposit, plus what you already owe.

option.title: Borrow money from a friend
option.facebookCopy: I can’t pay all my bills this month, and I need to borrow $225. Can you help me out?

option.title: Spent 0-15
option.copy: Almost 15 percent of American households had a hard time getting enough to eat at some point during 2009.

option.title: Spent 16-40
option.copy: Almost 15 percent of American households had a hard time getting enough to eat at some point during 2009.

option.title: Spent 41-60
option.copy: Almost 15 percent of American households had a hard time getting enough to eat at some point during 2009.

option.title: Hang up
option.copy: If you don’t make a payment, your car could be repossessed – just like the record 1.6 million autos that were repossessed in 2008.

challenge.title: Which Bill to Pay_Cell Phone or Insurance

option.title: Find somewhere else to live
option.copy: There are lots of places you could move – except they all require a security deposit and first/last month’s rent. So you’re stuck paying the money.

option.title: Ask a friend for help
option.facebookCopy: My kid and I are about to be evicted. We need somewhere to stay. Can we crash on your couch?

option.title: Ask a friend for help
option.facebookCopy: My car broke down and I’m stuck. Can you come get me? I can give you gas money.

option.title: Take your chances
option.copy:
You’ll save money in the short term, but you’ll have to pay a $100 late fee for waiting. And if you get pulled over, you’re looking at $1,500 to get your
car back.

option.title: Use some numbing gel
option.copy: One in four Americans doesn’t have dental insurance. And without coverage, putting off basic care could mean emergency surgery that’s twice as expensive.

option.title: Pay the minimum ($219)
option.copy: If you continue to pay only the minimum, the interest you have to pay means it will take you almost 17 years to pay off your card.

option.title: Ignore it
option.copy: Ignoring your bill makes your credit score plummet, so you’ll have a harder time finding a job or getting a loan.

option.title: Send your kid without a present
Keep your kid home from the party
Take the bus
option.copy: It takes three buses and five times longer to get to work than it would driving. So you lose a couple hours of pay.

option.title: Call in sick
option.copy: You skip work, but that day of pay would have filled up your gas tank.

option.title: Ask a friend for a ride
option.facebookCopy: I don’t have any gas in my car, and I’m broke. Can you give me a ride to work?

option.title: Don't pay
option.copy: Because your child didn’t have money for the field trip, they stayed at school in the office while the other children in the class went to the museum.

option.title: Call in sick
option.copy: Since your company doesn’t offer sick leave, that’s going to cost you a day of pay and count as a strike on your record. Hope you feel better tomorrow!

option.title: Go anyway
option.copy:
Like you, more than 40 million working Americans do not get paid sick leave. So, like you, they go to work, even when they
probably shouldn’t.

option.title: Call in sick
option.copy: Since your company doesn’t offer sick leave, that’s going to cost you a day of pay and count as a strike on your record. Hope you feel better tomorrow!

option.title: Go anyway
option.copy: Like you, more than 40 million working Americans do not get paid sick leave. So, like you, they go to work, even when they probably shouldn’t.

option.title: Stay home from work
option.copy: There goes another day of pay, plus another strike on your record.

option.title: Send them to school sick
option.copy: Like you, 39 percent of working families have had to send a child to school knowing they were sick.

option.title: Leave them home alone
option.copy: Now you know why a recent study found that parents in Baltimore, MD, were more likely to leave a sick child home alone all day than parents in Honduras.

option.title: Stay home from work
option.copy: There goes another day of pay, plus another strike on your record.

option.title: Send them to school sick
option.copy: Like you, 39 percent of working families have had to send a child to school knowing they were sick.

option.title: Leave them home alone
option.copy: Now you know why a recent study found that parents in Baltimore, MD, were more likely to leave a sick child home alone all day than parents in Honduras.

option.title: Buy a burger from the dollar menu
option.copy: It may be bad for you, but it sure is cheap. Perhaps that’s why low-income workers like you are more likely to be overweight.

option.title: Tell your friend you won’t be there
Tell your friend you won’t be there
Pay the damage ($550)
option.copy: Even if you have car insurance, high deductibles mean you still have to pay out of pocket.

option.title: Stay home
option.copy: Everyone needs a break sometimes, except not everyone can afford one. That’s probably why stress levels are higher among low-wage workers.

option.title: Pay $10 to play
option.copy: This isn’t your lucky week. But when you can’t afford a 401(k), the lottery is the closest thing you’ve got to an investment option.

option.title: Don’t play
option.copy: It may seem like a waste of money, but for people like you who have no 401(k) or savings account, it can look like an investment in a better future.

option.title: Give your child help
option.copy: Like many Americans, you don’t have high enough math skills to tutor your child. Guess they’re on their own.

option.title: Ask a friend for help
option.copy: You can’t help if you don’t know your stuff. What’s the answer to this math problem?
option.facebookCopy: My kid needs math help, but I can’t afford a tutor. Can you help?

option.title: Give your child help
option.copy: Luckily, you’re able to help your child out. Most Americans aren’t so lucky. A study found that more than 50 percent of parents have trouble helping their children with math and science.

option.title: Apply for a scholarship
option.copy:
To get the scholarship, you have to meet with a counselor in person, which will cost you half a
day of work.

option.title: Apply for a scholarship
option.copy: To get the scholarship, you have to meet with a counselor in person, which will cost you half a day of work.

option.title: Ask a friend
option.facebookCopy: I need to do laundry but can’t afford the Laundromat. Can I come over to your house?

option.title: Apply
option.copy: The good news is that you’re approved for benefits. The bad news? They don’t begin until next month.

option.title: Go hungry
option.copy: The USDA estimates that only 67% of Americans eligible for food stamps actually apply.

option.title: Ask a friend to take your pet
option.facebookCopy: I can’t afford to take care of my pet any more. Can you give it a home?

option.title: Take your pet to the animal shelter
Get a prescription for antidepressants ($175)
option.copy: You have to pay for the doctor visit. And the medicine isn’t free.

option.title: Talk to a therapist ($50)
option.copy: Even with a sliding scale, it’s still $50. And that’s just for one session.

option.title: Pretend you’re fine
option.copy: Now you understand why low-income Americans are the most likely to struggle with depression but are the least likely to seek treatment.

option.title: Get a prescription for antidepressants
option.copy: You have to pay for the doctor visit. And the medicine isn’t free.

option.title: Talk to a therapist
option.copy: Even with a sliding scale, it’s still $50. And that’s just for one session.

option.title: Pretend you’re fine
option.copy: Now you understand why low-income Americans are the most likely to struggle with depression but are the least likely to seek treatment.

option.title: Confess that it was you
option.copy: Your boss is infuriated that you hid the evidence and fires you on the spot. You don’t have to pay for the plates, but now you don’t have an income.

option.title: Keep quiet
option.copy: Your boss fires your co-worker. As she collects her things, she confides to you that she has no idea how she’ll take care of her two children.

option.title: Stay with an hourly paycheck
option.copy: Your hourly pay is higher than your co-worker’s who opted for the pay-by-the-piece system, but your supervisor cuts your hours to balance things out. Your future paychecks will be half the size.

option.title: Opt for the pay/piece system
option.copy: Even though you’re working as fast as you can, you just don’t make as much money as you made when you were being paid hourly. Your future paychecks will be about 25 percent lower.

option.title: Submit a workers’ comp claim
option.copy: Your supervisor laughs when you ask about filing a claim, then tells you there are plenty of other people willing to do your job.

option.title: Pay $25 to cover the broken item
Confess that it was you
option.copy: Your boss is infuriated that you hid the evidence and fires you on the spot. You don’t have to pay for the item, but now you don’t have an income.

option.title: Keep quiet
option.copy: Your boss fires your co-worker. As she collects her things, she confides to you that she has no idea how she’ll take care of her two children.

option.title: Add lunch money to your monthly budget ($3/day)
option.copy: $3 a day doesn’t seem like much, but a month of lunches takes a big bite out of your cash.

option.title: Risk them going hungry
option.copy: Your child isn’t the only one: Many children who qualify for free or reduced-cost lunch choose to go hungry rather than face the stigma of being identified as poor.

option.title: Talk to them
option.copy: Your manager finds out about your conversation and lets you go. Firing workers for union activity is illegal, but that doesn’t keep it from happening.

option.title: Keep walking
option.copy: Like you, many low-income workers would rather keep quiet than push for better working conditions because they don’t want to risk their jobs.

option.title: Take the job
option.copy: You’ll miss the play, but that $50 will make a difference. Which is a big reason parents with low incomes tend to be less involved in their children’s schooling and extracurricular activities.

option.title: Take the bus
option.copy: It takes three buses and five times longer to get to work than it would driving. So you lose a couple hours of pay.

option.title: Call in sick
option.copy: You skip work, but that day of pay would have filled up your gas tank.

option.title: Ask a friend for a ride
option.facebookCopy: I don’t have any gas in my car, and I’m broke. Can you give me a ride to work?

option.title: Get legal help
option.copy: You spend the whole day at the free legal clinic, only to find there’s a three-month waiting list for assistance of any kind. So you’re stuck paying the money.

option.title: Buy some plastic to put over the broken window ($5)
Get it checked out ($250)
option.copy: The good news is, the doctor says you’re fine. The bad news? Since you don’t have health insurance, you have to pay for the visit yourself.

option.title: Ignore it
option.copy: That’s a dangerous decision. Almost 1 million Americans die from treatable cardiovascular conditions each year.

option.title: Ask a friend to be your running buddy
option.facebookCopy: I’m trying to get healthier but don’t have the money for a gym membership. Will you work out with me?

option.title: Sign up for home Internet ($60 a month)
Get online at the public library
option.copy: For you and millions of other Americans, public library Internet access is a critical resource. Over 44% of people living below the poverty line visit the public library to get online.

option.title: Go without Internet
option.copy: Like you, 80 million American adults don’t have broadband or any Internet in their homes.

option.title: Wear the damaged one
option.copy: Your boss harangues you in front of the entire staff, then sends you home for the day, which means you just earned a job strike.

option.title: Try to fix it yourself
option.copy: Home improvement is cheaper when you do it yourself, but not free. Supplies still put you out $50.

option.title: Light up – it’s just one
option.copy: One of the main reasons people start smoking as adults is stress. There is a misconception that smoking relieves stress, so some people pick up the habit during difficult periods or life transitions.

option.title: Say no
option.copy: One of the main reasons people start smoking as adults is stress. There is a misconception that smoking relieves stress, so some people pick up the habit during difficult periods or life transitions.

option.title: Contest it in court
option.copy: You get the ticket dismissed, but you had to spend the whole day in court and pay a $50 court fee.

option.title: Say yes
option.copy: As Barbara Ehrenreich discovered in "Nickel and Dimed," high costs often force people to share housing.

option.title: Ask your landlord to evict him
option.copy: Your landlord won’t help you out, but will add another $100 to your rent for having an extra roommate.

option.title: Put up with it
option.copy: Many people are forced into complicated living situations like yours, simply because they can’t afford better options.

option.title: Ignore It
option.copy: Unemployment has hit college grads hard, and the college loan default rate proves it. In 2010, the default rate reached an 11-year high of 7 percent.

option.title: Get it checked out ($20)
option.copy: The doctor says you’re fine, and since you opted in for health insurance, you only have to pay $20.

option.title: Ignore it
option.copy: That’s a dangerous decision. Almost one million Americans die from treatable cardiovascular conditions each year.

option.title: Give up your car
option.copy: No car means you can’t get to work. Which means you’re out of a job. You won’t get any more paychecks, so your money is really going to have to stretch.

option.title: Pay to make icon go away
Pay $800 to make this go away
Pay $350 to make this go away
Pay $125 to make this go away
Pay $375 to make this go away
Pay $300 to make this go away
Pay $500 to make this go away
Pay $175 to make this go away
Pay $225 to make this go away
